text: Hmm, your version looks more intuitive :yao:. However, it will be a big change. I'd prefer adding a new API like `reorder_qubits!(reg, order) = reorder!(reg, sortperm(order))`  and expose this API to users rather than the `reorder!` .

elements.text: Hmm, your version looks more intuitive
. However, it will be a big change. I'd prefer adding a new API like
reorder_qubits!(reg, order) = reorder!(reg, sortperm(order))
and expose this API to users rather than the
reorder!

text: actually I always feel like letting the `bra_str` and `ket_str` support more operations based on the calling context instead of just symbolic types. The big endian convention on qubits makes more sense

Would be glad if you guys can give your suggestions on that!

Waiting 20secs for a bar graph to show up might be kinda off-putting for the readers. Especially when YaoPlots and Yao, take their own time.

text:
Also, the qubit readout using `readbit` is much more efficient than converting it to strings.
```julia> using BitBasis

julia> b = bit"10001111"
10001111 ₍₂₎

julia> using BenchmarkTools

julia> @benchmark readbit($b, 3)
BenchmarkTools.Trial: 
  memory estimate:  0 bytes
  allocs estimate:  0
  --------------
  minimum time:     0.016 ns (0.00% GC)
  median time:      0.018 ns (0.00% GC)
  mean time:        0.018 ns (0.00% GC)
  maximum time:     0.030 ns (0.00% GC)
  --------------
  samples:          10000
  evals/sample:     1000

julia> @benchmark readbit($b, 3, 2, 1)
BenchmarkTools.Trial: 
  memory estimate:  0 bytes
  allocs estimate:  0
  --------------
  minimum time:     1.479 ns (0.00% GC)
  median time:      1.487 ns (0.00% GC)
  mean time:        1.519 ns (0.00% GC)
  maximum time:     22.905 ns (0.00% GC)
  --------------
  samples:          10000
  evals/sample:     1000```

elements.text: Also, the qubit readout using
readbit
is much more efficient than converting it to strings.

julia> using BitBasis

julia> b = bit"10001111"
10001111 ₍₂₎

julia> using BenchmarkTools

julia> @benchmark readbit($b, 3)
BenchmarkTools.Trial: 
  memory estimate:  0 bytes
  allocs estimate:  0
  --------------
  minimum time:     0.016 ns (0.00% GC)
  median time:      0.018 ns (0.00% GC)
  mean time:        0.018 ns (0.00% GC)
  maximum time:     0.030 ns (0.00% GC)
  --------------
  samples:          10000
  evals/sample:     1000

julia> @benchmark readbit($b, 3, 2, 1)
BenchmarkTools.Trial: 
  memory estimate:  0 bytes
  allocs estimate:  0
  --------------
  minimum time:     1.479 ns (0.00% GC)
  median time:      1.487 ns (0.00% GC)
  mean time:        1.519 ns (0.00% GC)
  maximum time:     22.905 ns (0.00% GC)
  --------------
  samples:          10000
  evals/sample:     1000
